results.title: Flowering plants and their parts
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner, Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Life Science”.
Relates the roots, stems and leaves of plants to plant growth and reproduction. Illustrates the ability of plants to adapt to their environment.

results.title: Flowergirl
results.creator_credit: Anthony Anderson, Red Carpet Productions and Cate Shortland
results.brief_description: Daisuke, Hana and Tetsu are three young Japanese tourists who share a flat in Sydney’s Bondi Beach. Daisuke has to return to Japan to work in his father’s butcher shop but his return is made bitter because of his falling in love with Hana. Featuring a fragmented narrative utilising video and 16mm film, this beautifully shot short film was voted the Best Short Film of 1999 by the Critic’s Circle of Australia.

results.title: Flower stories
results.creator_credit: Terry Harding, HTV West, Taurus-Film, Richard Price Television and Kate Canning
results.brief_description: A compilation of 8 animated stories aimed to entertain children aged between 3-9 years and featuring James, a fat black and white cat. The central theme for all the stories is “flowers”. Very colorful! Animation by Sue Allen. Storyteller: Alan Taylor.

results.title: Flower gardens
results.creator_credit: Stuart Crowner, Bruce Franchini and Perennial Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Gardens of the world”.
Perhaps no garden in the world exhibits a more exhilirating use of flowers than Claude Monet’s garden at Giverny. Monet’s exuberant palette of colours strikingly contrasts with the grace and elegance of the classic perennial borders found at Tintinhull House in Somerset, England. The native flora of America’s southeast further illustrate the range of aesthetics and pleasure found in the world’s most beautiful flower gardens. Hosted by Audrey Hepburn and narrated by Michael York.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stuart Crowner, Bruce Franchini and Perennial Productions

results.title: Flower buds
results.creator_credit: Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People's Republic of China
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “China Today”.
This film covers cultural aspects of children’s lives in China such as dance, children’s orchestra, singing, folk-dance, traditional music and instruments. Non-stylised overview of traditional cultural traditions as demonstrated by children.

results.title: Florence: cradle of the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Leah Joy and Museum Television Workshop
results.brief_description: Narrated by Grace Jackman, with poetry and readings inspired by Florence, and read by Richard Levine, viewers are taken on an artistic travelogue of Florence, focusing primarily on the Renaissance. This commentary provides insight into the architectural and artistic wonders which are an integral part of Florence. From 1436 when Brunelleschi designed the dome of Santa Maria del Fiore, the next hundred years of the Renaissance were filled with seminal figures like Michelangelo, Botticelli, Ghiberti, Cellini, Donatello and Leonardo da Vinci; overlooked by the great patrons Cosimo and Lorenzo de Medici. This video enables the viewer to experience the masterpieces of Florence as an armchair traveller.

results.title: Florence [Videogame Archive]
results.brief_description:
Expertly blending the visual novel and gaming genres, Florence illustrates one year in the life of a young woman in Melbourne as she falls in love, breaks her daily routine and follows her creative passion.

Developed by Australian craft games studio Mountains, Florence uses innovative gameplay mechanics to represent social interactions. The emotions of the poignant narrative are rendered through tapping and swiping minigames, making them all the more touching.

The archive spans a variety of paraphernalia from Florence’s creation, including storyboards, early character designs, unused game concepts, musical samples and feedback from game testers. It provides invaluable insight on the game development process and the path Mountains took in making their award-winning game.
